qas.question: What are all USB On-The-Go devices required to have?

answers.text: one, and only one, USB connector

qas.question: Non-OTG compliant devices are not allowed to use what?
Why are the Non-OTG compliant devices not allowed to use the micro-AB receptacle?

answers.text: power supply shorting hazards on the VBUS line

context: All current USB On-The-Go (OTG) devices are required to have <a0_0>one, and only one, USB connector<a0_0/>: a micro-AB receptacle. Non-OTG compliant devices are not allowed to use <a1_0>the micro-AB receptacle<a1_0/>, due to <a2_0>power supply shorting hazards on the VBUS line<a2_0/>. The micro-AB receptacle is capable of accepting both micro-A and micro-B plugs, attached to any of the legal cables and adapters as defined in revision 1.01 of the micro-USB specification. Prior to the development of micro-USB, USB On-The-Go devices were required to use mini-AB receptacles to perform the equivalent job.
